title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Welcome!
Welcome to today‚Äôs SSC Virtual Skills Workshop.
I‚Äôm Grace! I‚Äôm a;

Recent Biostatistics PhD graduate (University of Waterloo, 2025)
New Assistant Professor of Teaching (UBC, July 2025)
Person who suffered greatly trying to learn how to use GitHub ü´†

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: What is your experience with Git/GitHub?
text:
What is your experience with Git/GitHub?
Let me know in the chat! Some possible answers:

I use it confidently all of the time
I use it but it scares me
I tried to use it once or twice
I‚Äôve never used it
I‚Äôve never even heard of it

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Git

A free, open source version control system designed to track changes
Creates ‚Äúsnapshots‚Äù of your work as your progress through a project

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
GitHub

Cloud-based platform for storing, managing, and collaborating
Uses Git (hence the name)!

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Before We Start the Demo‚Ä¶.

You can follow along live (two screens/devices recommended), or watch and set up your own accounts later.
I have accompanying YouTube videos covering every single step, so if you miss something, you can refer back to it.
I have course notes from a class at UBC that had a section on GitHub that you are welcome to reference!

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Demo
In this workshop, we will do the following:

Set up Git on RStudio
Connect RStudio to GitHub
Connect an existing R Project to GitHub (‚ÄúR First‚Äù)

Make changes locally and on GitHub, and sync them

Clone a GitHub repository to R Studio (‚ÄúGitHub First‚Äù)

Make changes locally and on GitHub, and sync them

Create READMEs
(If time permits) Explore the use of branches

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.1: Sign up for a GitHub account

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.2: Install Git

For Mac OS, on the Terminal (Mac) type which git. For Windows, go to Command Prompt and type where git. If you get an error of git: command not found, you do not have git installed yet. To install:

Windows:

Install Git for Windows (https://gitforwindows.org/)
When asked about ‚ÄúAdjusting your PATH environment‚Äù, make sure to select ‚ÄúGit from the command line and also from 3rd-party software‚Äù. Otherwise, keep the defaults.

Mac OS:

Install XCode Command Line Tools by opening Terminal and typing xcode-select --install (more info here)
In Terminal, enter git config. Click install.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.3: Configure Git in R

Within the Terminal (Mac) or Shell (Windows) (Tools > Terminal/Shell) do

git config --global user.name "your_github_username"
git config --global user.email "your_email_you_used_for_github@example.com"


(If you are having issues, you could use the usethis package in R. See here.)

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.4: Configure Your Personal Access Token (PAT)

Option 1: Go to to https://github.com/settings/tokens and click ‚ÄúGenerate token‚Äù.

Choose Classic Token
Describe the token‚Äôs purpose in the Note field, e.g.¬†‚Äúpersonal-macbook‚Äù or ‚ÄúStat545Installation‚Äù
Select ‚Äúrepo‚Äù, ‚Äúuser‚Äù, and ‚Äúworkflow‚Äù for scopes
Set an expiry date (can regenerate tokens later)
Save this token somewhere so you can use it again later, such as a password manager

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.4: Configure Your Personal Access Token (PAT) (con‚Äôt)

Option 2: From R, execute usethis::create_github_token() in the Console (you may have to install the usethis package first by first running install.packages("usethis")).

Describe the token‚Äôs purpose in the Note field
Set an expiry date (can regenerate tokens later)
Save this token somewhere so you can use it again later, such as a password manager

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.4: Configure Your Personal Access Token (PAT) (con‚Äôt)
Regardless of how you generated your PAT, you now need to:

Run install.packages("gitcreds") in the Console
Run gitcreds::gitcreds_set() and enter the PAT that you just made when prompted

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
text:
Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
Step 2.1: Initialize Git

Load in the usethis package by calling library(usethis) in the Console.
Then, run use_git().
When asked to commit changes, select the option that means yes. Restart RStudio if needed.

You should now see a ‚ÄúGit‚Äù pane by your Environment/History/Connections.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
text:
Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
Step 2.2: Create a GitHub Repository for an Existing Project

Run library(usethis) in the Console
Then, in the Console run use_github().
A new repository on your GitHub account with the same name as your R Project should be created! Head to your GitHub account to check it out.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 3: Connect RStudio to an Existing GitHub Repository
text:
Part 3: Connect RStudio to an Existing GitHub Repository
Step 3.1: Copy link to repository

Navigate to the repository you want to clone on GitHub.
Clicking the green ‚ÄúCode‚Äù button to copy the address of the repository.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 3: Connect RStudio to an Existing GitHub Repository
text:
Part 3: Connect RStudio to an Existing GitHub Repository
Step 3.2: Clone the Repository

In RStudio, go to ‚ÄúFile > New Project‚Äù
Click on ‚ÄúVersion Control: Checkout a project from a version control repository‚Äù
Click on ‚ÄúGit: Clone a project from a repository‚Äù
Fill in the details:

URL: use the HTTPS address (from Step 3.1)
Create as a subdirectory of: Browse to where you would like to save this repository on your machine (creates a new folder in the location you select)


Now you have a local version of this project!
ADD IMAGE OF DEMO PROJECT

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 3: Connect RStudio to an Existing GitHub Repository
text:
Part 3: Connect RStudio to an Existing GitHub Repository
Side note:

You can clone any public project, however you need to be added as a collaborator to push those changes to GitHub.
If you‚Äôd like to play around with existing repositories, you could ‚ÄúFork‚Äù it. A fork is a copy of a repository. Forking a repository allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project. More info here: https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/fork-a-repo.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Ways I‚Äôve Used GitHub

Thesis/independent research projects
Consulting (collaborative work)
Teaching (all! the! time!)
Website Creation
Documenting issues on R Packages

(I even got asked about my GitHub experiences in my UBC interview!)

title: My first two months
text:
I‚Äôve now been teaching both graduate and undergraduate for two full months! I must say, although the imposter syndrome creeps in and I have days where I doubt myself, I am really enjoying my job.
One thing I‚Äôm really enjoying is making my YouTube tutorials. It helps me prep for my STAT545 lecture, almost acting as a practice run, and allows me to use my video editing and social media experience in a creative way. I‚Äôve heard that my students are also enjoying them, and sharing them with their friends in their labs who are looking to learn about doing research with R! I hope that I can teach STAT545 again so I can reuse my videos next year!
I am also so impressed with my students this term. They really surprise me everyday (in mostly good ways!). They are so creative, driven, and such a joy to be around. It‚Äôs hard to believe this term has only four weeks of classes left before the exam period, and then another group of students will be in my classroom.
Two months down and many more (hopefully) to go!

title: Reflecting on 2025 and Plans for 2026
text:
2025 Recap
2025 brought so much joy in my personal and professional life. I defended my PhD, spent a month in Japan, moved to Vancouver, snuck in a few visits home on the East Coast, got really into pottery, and started my career as an Assistant Professor of Teaching.
I remember grinding out my thesis last January just hoping and praying that I would pass the defense, and that my work would be enough. I was never very confident as a researcher, and I missed teaching so much. I had applied to a teaching stream position at UBC a month prior with only hopes of getting an interview. I had no idea how much my life would change over the next year.
STAT545 was such a fun course - I really loved getting creative and having autonomy over the material. I also LOVED teaching grad students! I learned all about Quarto, and started my little YouTube channel with mini-lectures that followed the course‚Äôs content. While I know I can‚Äôt please them all, I left the course with the impression that most of my students enjoyed it, and felt that they had learned real skills that would help them out as budding researchers. These students were amazing - I hope I‚Äôm lucky enough to have a class like them again next year.
DSCI100 was unlike anything that I had taught before. Every lecture was pre-made and meticulously scheduled, and there were sooo many students/sections. At first, I honestly found it tough to be lecturing off of slides that I hadn‚Äôt made, using a platform I was unfamiliar with. I still don‚Äôt like RISE/Jupyter (lol) but in the end, I grew to really appreciate the minimal administrative work that this course entailed. It allowed me to focus more of my time on the students - offering extra office hours, monitoring Piazza (a bit obsessively, perhaps) and hosting an exam review session. I was able to fill in for my colleagues when needed, as well. I learned that many students appreciated my enthusiastic nature (again, not all of them. Some called me corny) and it allowed me to be more confident at the podium. I also really appreciated my colleagues in this course. The were so patient, experienced, and willing to help out the newbie.
I also snuck in some training - I started the Teaching Development Program for New Faculty, which included a 24-hour Instructional Skills Workshop. I‚Äôm really enjoying this program so far, and am looking forward to attending more workshops in the Winter term. I‚Äôm also currently completing the Fundamentals of OCAP course to learn more about Indigenous Data Sovereignty. I plan to weave in the principals of OCAP into my future courses, and am starting to work on a repository focusing on Indigenizing Statistics and Data Science Undergraduate Courses.
I‚Äôm really proud of what I accomplished in my first term at UBC. All I wanted to do was support my students and teach them the absolute best that I could. I definitely gave it my best shot.


2026 Goals
I‚Äôm setting reasonable goals this year.
Along side my usual teaching duties I really want to work more on the Indigenizing Statistics and Data Science Undergraduate Courses project that I previously mentioned. I feel as though I have a solid foundation to start reaching out to other faculty members (perhaps in other departments) to see if they‚Äôre interested in contributing to this project. This is one that I‚Äôm really excited about!
I also want to continue to grow my YouTube video catalog and add more topics, including those that go hand-in-hand with DSCI 100! That was something that was requested by my students last term (they requested this at the end of the term so it wasn‚Äôt feasible for me to get it done for my last cohort of students).
This term, I‚Äôm also going to be better with my boundaries. No 24/7 Slack monitoring. Emails can wait. Piazza can wait. I need to let my evenings be for myself and my own wellness. More walks! More crafting! Less screen time. Less working on days off (I say as I write this over my Holiday break‚Ä¶).
I can only hope 2026 is half as good as 2025. Here‚Äôs to the new year!

title: Requests
text:
For any of the following requests, please email me at grace <-at> stat.ubc.ca or fill out the form at the bottom of this page.

üåø Mentoring
I am very eager to provide mentoring to undergraduate and graduate students! This will provide students with an opportunity to form meaningful connections and get advice on majors/minors, graduate school, careers, and more.
I am happy to meet to discuss non-course related topics. Please reach out and we can set a time to meet either in person or over Zoom.


‚úâÔ∏è Invitations for Conference, Seminars, Workshops, and Talks
I would love to give a talk on any of my projects or provide a workshop on R coding, GitHub, or any other statistics or data science topic that is relevant to my work.


üë©‚Äçüî¨ Supervising
I am a Teaching Stream faculty member, so I am not currently supervising students. Please reach out to other Professors in the department who are not indicated as being ‚ÄúTeaching Stream‚Äù.


üóÇÔ∏è Graduate Academic Assistantships (GAAs - Masters, and PhD students only)
I am not actively looking for students, but if you‚Äôd like to be involved in my future Educational Leadership (teaching-related) projects, feel free to reach out. If a project come up where a graduate student could be hired, I will let you know!


üìù Reference Requests
I am happy to provide reference letters for Graduate programs, internships, and employment for students that I know well. This includes:

Current and former students I‚Äôve taught more than one time
Current and former students I‚Äôve taught only once, but were active in class and attended office hours
Current and former students I‚Äôve met through committees and can speak to their out-of-class activities

My Reference Letter Policy:

I can write up to 5 references per student per term. These include reference letters for graduate schools, jobs, and scholarships.
I need at least 3 weeks to write a reference.
I need to agree to every reference request BEFORE you write my name down as a reference. Please do not assume!
You must provide me with a list of reference letters you need, and details on each application, including the due date, where I submit, what the application is for, and any other information that I may need to write your reference letter. Please compile this into a clear email or document that I can reference.

For example, if you are applying to a graduate program I highly recommend sending:

information on where I submit to (online? via email?)
a link to the program/scholarship you are applying to, along with a brief description about the program
details about why you are applying to a particular school/program
your career goals or future plans
a CV
transcripts
any other information you may think is relevant.


   Leave a note with your request and I'll get back to you.

title: I‚Äôm a Blogger Now?
text:
I recently enrolled in a Teaching Development Program (TDP) and in one of the modules we discussed Reflective Teaching. We don‚Äôt tend to see much of this in Statistics. Personally, throughout my undergraduate (and graduate) courses not once did anyone ask how I felt or what I thought. Everything was very structured, right or wrong, yes or no, proved correctly or not, with little room to reflect. I was encouraged by the TDP team to start a blog to do more reflection.
This blog will serve as a space to collect my jumbled thoughts, and perhaps spark a conversation. I‚Äôll be giving some reflections as I grow throughout this new role, and share resources and stories as I see fit.
Thanks for reading!
